section.title: How Do I Set Logging Levels For Services?
section.p: When it is necessary to increase the logging level for a specific service to troubleshoot an issue, or to decrease logging levels to save disk space, you can edit the service's config file and then reconfigure logging.

Messages only appear in the log files if they are the same as or more severe than the log level you set. The DEBUG level logs everything. Most services default to the INFO logging level, which lists informational events, plus warnings, errors, and critical errors. Some services provide other logging options which will narrow the focus to help you debug an issue, receive a warning if an operation fails, or if there is a serious issue with the cloud.

ul.li: To review very detailed output for diagnostic purposes.
If a developer needs copious details to understand what is going on with the service.

row.entry: Every message is logged including those that are only for debugging. Provides detailed information, typically of interest only when diagnosing problems. The information can be used to diagnose problems by developers, IT, and system administrators.

ul.li: To confirm that things are working as expected, if you want to report events that occur during the normal operation of a program.
For example: status monitoring or fault investigation.

row.entry: This is the default log level. It includes main events. For example, this includes information about when the service starts and stops, and service configuration assumptions.

ul.li: To confirm that things are working as expected, if you want to report events that occur during the normal operation of a program.
For example: status monitoring or fault investigation.

row.entry: This is the default log level. It includes main events. For example, this includes information about when the service starts and stops, and service configuration assumptions.

ul.li: To force a user to respond. For example, if a connection string is incorrect.
To immediately notify an administrator by email or pager when there is a serious issue with the cloud.
To report suppression of an error without raising an exception. For example, an error handler in a long-running server process.

row.entry: Indicates that due to a more serious problem, the software has not been able to perform some function. Entries include any error which is fatal to the operation but not the service or application. Examples: Can't open a required file, or missing data.
To be alerted when a critical error occurs that can lead to service interruption or degradation.
Identifies an unrecoverable error with a service. Entries indicate a serious error where the program itself may be unable to continue running.

section.p: If you want to increase or decrease the amount of details that are logged by a service, you can change the current logging level in the configuration files. Most services support, at a minimum, the DEBUG and INFO logging levels. For more information about what levels are supported by a service, check the documentation or Website for the specific service.

section.title: How Do I Change the Length of Time Log Files Are Retained?
section.p:
As you use each service, you might need change the default configuration settings such as:
which files are rotated
how often they are rotated
how large they can grow before being rotated Helion Openstack uses the cron process which in turn calls logrotate to provide rotation, compression, and removal of log files. Each log file can be checked hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly. If no rotation period is set then the log file will only be rotated when it grows too large.

You can find the configuration files for each service in the following directory: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/* Only files that have centralized logging enabled are copied to Elasticsearch.
All of the variables for the logrotate process are found in the following file: ../logging-ansible/logging-common/defaults/main.yml
All of the variables for logging are found in the following file: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/defaults/main.yml

p.b: To change log rotation settings for a service:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Change to the sub-directory for the service you want to modify: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/*
Using BURA as an example: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/BURA

Open the *.yml file for the service or sub-component that you want to modify.
Using BURA as an example: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/BURA/freezer-agent-clr.yml

Verify logging is enabled by locating the following line: --- - centralized_logging: enabled: true
Using BURA as an example: --- sub_service: name: freezer-agent service: freezer logging_options: - centralized_logging: enabled: true
To change the frequency, which is the timing of when the logs are rotated, change the following line: log_rotate: - daily Options include: Hourly, Daily, Weekly, Monthly
To rotate a file based on its size, set the maximum size the log file can be before it is rotated out: - maxsize 80M
To change the number of log files that are rotated, change the following line: rotate 14
Save the changes to the file.
To commit the changes to your local git repository: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
To run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
To create a deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
To run the logging reconfigure playbook: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts bura-reconfigure.yml

section.p:
Using BURA as an example, I want to change the log rotation settings to the following:
the freezer-agent service to create log entries
the log files to be created on a daily basis
the maximum size the file can grow before it is rotated out to be 80MB.
the number of updated copies of an original log file that are kept locally on the server and will continue to be rotated to be 14 files.
the files to be indexed by Elasticsearch and available for searching

To create this scenario I would use the following steps:
Log in to the lifecycle manager.
Change to the directory: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/BURA
Open the following file: .../logging-ansible/logging-common/vars/BURA/freezer-agent-clr.yml
Enable logging by editing the following line to true: --- - centralized_logging: enabled: false
Configure the frequency by changing the following line: log_rotate: - daily
Set the maximum size the log file can be before it is rotated out: - maxsize 80M
Change the number of log files that are rotated to 14: rotate 14
Save the changes to the file.
To commit the changes to your local git repository: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
To run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
To create a deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
To run the logging reconfigure playbook: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts bura-reconfigure.yml
Sample file created by the above steps:
section.codeblock: --- sub_service: name: freezer-agent service: freezer logging_options: - centralized_logging: enabled: false format: json files: - /var/log/freezer-agent/freezer-agent.log log_rotate: - daily - compress - missingok - notifempty - copytruncate - maxsize 80M - rotate 14

section.title: How Do I Configure Kibana for Centralized Logging?
section.p: You can use the Kibana dashboards to view log data. Kibana is a tool developed to create charts, graphs, tables, and histograms based on logs send to Elasticsearch by logstash.

While creating Kibana dashboards is beyond the scope of this document, it is important to know that you can use the default Kibana dashboards or create custom dashboards. The dashboards are JSON files that you can modify or create new dashboards based on existing dashboards.
section.note: Kibana is client-side software. To operate properly, the browser must be able to access port 5601 on the control plane.
section.p: The access information for Kibana is defined in the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml file and implemented in the Kibana configuration file ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/kibana-apache2.conf.j2.

row.entry: Username that will be required for logging into the Kibana UI.
Password generated during installation that is used to login to the Kibana UI.

section.p: To log into Kibana to view data, you must either access Kibana through Operations Console or using a direct link. Then make sure you have the correct login credentials.

ol.li: Access Kibana using the Operations Console or through a direct link.
Verify login credentials.
Access Operations Console.
From the menu, choose Logging Dashboard.

section.p: This section helps you verify the Horizon virtual IP (VIP) address for Kibana that you should use.

ol.li: Navigate to and open in a text editor the following file: network_groups.yml
Find the following entry: external-name
If your administrator set a hostname value in the external-name field during the configuration process for your cloud, then Kibana will be accessed over port 5601 on that hostname.

If your administrator did not set a hostname value, then to determine which IP address to use, from your lifecycle manager, run: grep vip-HZN-WEB /etc/hosts
The output of that command will show you the virtual IP address for Kibana that you should use. Access to Kibana will be over port 5601 of that virtual IP address. Example:http://<VIP>:5601

section.p: During the installation of Kibana, a password is automatically set and it is randomized. Therefore, unless an administrator has already changed it, you need to retreive the default password from a file on the control plane node.
The default settings for Kibana are:

ol.li: On your lifecycle manager, navigate to the following directory: ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/group_vars/*
To GREP for the logging_kibana_password, run: grep logging_kibana_password <name-of-control-plane>

section.note: For example, if you are using the Entry-scale KVM with VSA model and you kept the default naming scheme in the example files then your command would look similar to this: grep logging_kibana_password entry-scale-kvm-vsa-control-plane-1

section.title: How Do I Configure Elasticsearch for Centralized Logging?
section.p: Elasticsearch includes some tunable options exposed in its configuration. Helion uses these options in Elasticsearch to prioritize indexing speed over search speed. Helion also configures Elasticsearch for optimal performance in low RAM environments. The options that Helion modifies are listed below along with an explanation about why they were modified.

These configurations are defined in the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml file and are implemented in the Elasticsearch configuration file ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/elasticsearch.yml.j2.

row.entry: Name of the Elasticsearch cluster. This variable cannot be changed after the initial deployment. Doing so will reset all Elasticsearch indices.
By default, this setting is unboundedElasticsearch will never evict data from fielddata, which is less than ideal when trying to conserve on memory usage.
The field data circuit breaker enables Elasticsearch to estimate the amount of memory a field will require to be loaded into memory. This value must be greater than cache.size to evict data properly.

By default, this setting is -1 (i.e., never expires).
